properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of freezing rain are expected Thursday night. The amount of ice accretion amounts in the range of 2 to 5 millimetres. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T12:47:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T20:48:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1559520501.2019
Area: Low - Wakefield area, Maniwaki - Gracefield area, Papineauville - Chénéville area, Papineau-Labelle Reserve area, Lièvre River area, Saint-Michel-des-Saints area, Saint-Donat - Mont-Tremblant Park area, Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area, Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected inland on Thursday and Thursday night. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: inland portions of the northeast coast. Time span: Thursday morning until Friday morning. Remarks: Precipitation is forecast to remain mostly as rain along the coast but snow is expected further inland where accumulations of up to 10 cm are expected. However, local accumulations of 15 cm inland are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-21T18:03:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T02:04:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2822885332.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected to begin Thursday morning and end Thursday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T12:28:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T20:29:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2527160207.2019
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall accumulations of near 15 cm expected. Locations: Gander, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, and inland portions of the Bay d'Espoir Highway. Time span: late Thursday morning to near midnight Thursday. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Thursday morning and become heavy at times early Thursday afternoon. Snow is forecast to taper off to flurries or drizzle overnight Thursday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-21T11:27:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T19:28:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3611684822.2019
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow tonight and Thursday. Snow will begin near Lake Superior near midnight and spread eastward towards the Quebec border by Thursday morning. Snowfall amounts in the 15 to 20 cm range can be expected before the snow tapers off late Thursday or Thursday night. Areas closer to the shores of Lake Superior will receive slightly less snowfall as the precipitation will begin as rain and only change over to snow Thursday night. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system that will track south of the region. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T12:51:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T20:52:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1715321572.2019
Area: Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard today and tonight. A low pressure system is bringing snow and blowing snow to areas along the Hudson Bay coast. Winds have strengthened to north 50 or 60 km/h in the area with locally stronger gusts and dropping temperatures. This combination will allow visibilities to drop to the blizzard criterion of 400 metres. Blizzard conditions will start easing at Arviat this evening and at Rankin Inlet Thursday morning as the snow pulls out and winds start to diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T07:39:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T15:40:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3280008112.2019
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system is approaching from the west. Strong southerly winds ahead of the low is expected to give blizzard conditions starting Thursday morning. The blizzard should continue until Thursday night when the low moves far enough east. Winter Storm Watches are issued when blizzard conditions are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T07:30:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T15:31:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2168611390.2019
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-21T16:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-20T14:48:31-06:00, BAA60F0C-34BA-4603-6AEE-543560DDE397
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall on Thursday and Thursday night. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: Newfoundland's interior. Time span: Thursday morning to Friday morning. Remarks: A developing storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall to the island. The heaviest snowfall will occur over Newfoundland's interior, with more of a mixture of snow and rain closer to the coast. Along Newfoundland's east coast, precipitation will fall mostly as rain. The location and total of the maximum snowfall amounts remains uncertain at this time. Temperatures are expected to be mild, which may lead to significantly reduced accumulation. Variations in the track of the system could also shift where the most snow is expected to fall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-21T06:18:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T14:19:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0963934286.2019
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight into Thursday. Snow will begin tonight over portions of Northwestern Ontario spreading eastward towards the Quebec border by Thursday morning. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible by the time the snow ends on Thursday. Areas closer to the shores of Lake Superior may begin as rain and receive less snowfall, particularly areas east of Marathon. There remains uncertainty regarding the exact location of the highest snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required for some regions. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system that will track south of the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T12:52:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-20T20:53:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1703767108.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system is crossing central Yukon this afternoon and tonight, spreading snow heavy at times to the Mayo region. 10 cm of snow can be expected before the snow tapers off overnight as the system moves to the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T14:14:30-00:00
